He had,however, no statutory powers over the agencies established in India,for purposes of political warfare, by Departments of His Majesty'sGovernment in the United Kingdom, It was therefore suggestedthat he, should now be given specific authority, in his personal capacity and not as Viceroy, to settle on behalf of His Majesty'sGovernment, by direct instructions to those agencies in Indiamatters relating to the conduct of political warfare against japan on which prompt orders were required for the purpose ofco-ordinating the functions of those agencies with those of Depart-ments of the Government of India. It was proposed that this authority should be given in the form of a Directive, the draft ofwhich Was reproduced as an Appendix to the Memorandum.The War Cabinet were informed that this proposal had thesupport of the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, the Secretaryof State for War and the Minister of Information -though theSecretary of State for Foreign Affairs wished to reserve for laterdiscussion the questions of the appropriate channel of communica-tion with the Viceroy, the need for a political adviser to be attachedto him; and the arrangements which, would be necessitated by theappointment of a Supreme Commander for the South-East AsiaCommand.The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs said that the reservations which he had made were concerned with wider issuesaffecting the relations between the Viceroy and the Foreign office in matters of foreign policy in respect Of the Far East. He wouldbe glad if a senior official from, the Foreign Office could be appointedto the personal staff of the Viceroy as his adviser on foreign affairs;and, if such an appointment were made, questions would ariseregarding the channel of communication between this adviser andthe Foreign Office. He contemplated that, if at a later stage the headquarters of the SoUth-East Asia Command were moved outsideIndia, the Supreme Commander should have on his staff an adviser on foreign affairs; and it would; be important to preserve continuity,possibly by arranging that the Viceroy's personal adviser on foreignaffairs should at that stage be transferred to the supreme commander.The War Cabinet had some preliminary discussion of thesequestions. It was, however, agreed that they required furtherconsideration; and that meanwhile there was no reason to delay theissue of the proposed."
